node.title: Cannot calculate  TENSOR_MECHANICS correctly
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am new to MOOSE. I followed the tutorial on youtube（https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9plLYkAbvQ&list=TLPQMDcwNzIwMjEvnbj3LWAiyQ&index=6）to do a FEM calculation of the piston, and used the correct files in the tutorial, no matter whether I updated the MOOSE and Conda in advance, my MOOSE results are as shown in the picture. Before the calculation, I have modified the Makefile, opened TENSOR_MECHANICS, and recompiled.
I want to know how to calculate it correctly?
Thank you!

@ScouperLH
You need to share the input file for help.
It looks like your simulation runs though.
Nicolò

thank you for your reply! My input file is as follows. I don't see the kernel file in the app after compiling. Is it because I am using the built-in TENSOR_MECH of MOOSE?
[Mesh]
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z' #Define displacements for deformed mesh
type = FileMesh #Read in mesh from file
file = piston_coarse.e
[]
[./Adaptivity]
steps = 1
#initial_steps = 2
max_h_level = 3
cycles_per_step = 1
initial_marker = uniform
marker = errorFraction
[./Markers]
[./uniform]
type = UniformMarker
mark = refine
[../]
[./errorFraction]
  type = ErrorFractionMarker
  coarsen = 0.5
  indicator = gradientJump
  refine = 0.5
[] 

[../]
[./Indicators]
[./gradientJump]
type = GradientJumpIndicator
variable = disp_y
[]
[]
[../]
[Variables]
[./disp_x]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[./disp_y]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[./disp_z]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[]
[Kernels]
[./TensorMechanics]
#Stress divergence kernels
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[../]
[]
[AuxVariables]
[./von_mises]
#Dependent variable used to visualize the Von Mises stress
order = CONSTANT
family = MONOMIAL
[../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
[./von_mises_kernel]
#Calculates the von mises stress and assigns it to von_mises
type = RankTwoScalarAux
variable = von_mises
rank_two_tensor = stress
execute_on = timestep_end
scalar_type = VonMisesStress
[../]
[]
[Functions]
[./rampLinear]
type = ParsedFunction
value = t*550e5
[]
[]
[BCs]
[./Pressure]
[./load]
#Applies the pressure
boundary = load_surf
function = rampLinear
disp_x = disp_x
disp_y = disp_y
disp_z = disp_z
[../]
[../]
[./symmetry_x]
#Applies symmetry on the xmin faces
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_x
boundary = 'xmin'
value = 0.0
[../]
[./hold_y]
#Anchors the bottom against deformation in the y-direction
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = 'ymin'
value = 0.0
[../]
[./symmetry_z]
#Applies symmetry on the zmin faces
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_z
boundary = 'zmin'
value = 0.0
[../]
[]
[Materials]
active = 'density_steel stress strain elasticity_tensor_steel'
[./elasticity_tensor_steel]
#Creates the elasticity tensor using steel parameters
youngs_modulus = 210e9 #Pa
poissons_ratio = 0.3
type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
block = 1
[../]
[./strain]
#Computes the strain, assuming small strains
type = ComputeFiniteStrain
block = 1
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[../]
[./stress]
#Computes the stress, using linear elasticity
type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
block = 1
[../]
[./density_steel]
#Defines the density of steel
type = GenericConstantMaterial
block = 1
prop_names = density
prop_values = 7850 # kg/m^3
[../]
[]
[Preconditioning]
[./SMP]
#Creates the entire Jacobian, for the Newton solve
type = SMP
full = true
[../]
[]
[Executioner]
#We solve a steady state problem using Newton's iteration
type = Transient
solve_type = NEWTON
nl_rel_tol = 1e-9
l_max_its = 30
l_tol = 1e-4
nl_max_its = 10
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg 31'
dt = 0.1
num_steps = 10
[]
[Outputs]
exodus = true
perf_graph = true
[]

You should modify your pressure BC.
Looking at the source code of the PressureAction, you should provide the displacements as a vector displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z' instead of providing the three displacement variables separately.
Your BC should look like that:
[./Pressure]
  [./load]
    #Applies the pressure
	boundary = load_surf
	function = rampLinear
	displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  [../]
Thank you! I modified it accordingly, and it works!
@GregVernon this is a nice tutorial. I suggest to check it into the tensor mechanics module as an example, and enable at least syntax check so that it doesn't break in the future.
Will do!

Now that this is merged, I think it'd be great if you can somehow point viewers of that YouTube tutorial to the updated input file. I'm not a YouTube expert, but I think that's doable. Anyways, it's your call.
Yep - I'll do that today!

node.title: symmertric9 fill method with in a 2D simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I was wondering if I could use the symmetric9 fill method with a 2D mesh.
Thanks,
Leon
Yes
To eleborate, our tensors and vectors are always 3D, no matter the mesh.
Got it, thanks, @hugary1995 and @dschwen.

node.title: Question about ParsedMaterial v ParsedFunction
node.bodyText:
I want a "material property" that is a user defined function of time only. In my input file, under the materials block, I have the following:
  [m_inf]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    f_name = m_inf
    function = 't + 3*t'
    outputs = exodus
  []

However I get an error when I try to run this. From the documentation, my understanding is that ParsedMaterial is an "extended" form of ParsedFunction where you can also add variables you're solving for, (e.g displacement) into the function, is that correct? But ParsedFunction only recognizes x,y,z and t. Why then, is this not running?
Also, if I were to use ADParsedFunction, and created this under a "Functions" block, would I still be able to use it in my Material Interface?
Also, when retrieving this from the input file, in my material file, I have:
_m_inf(getADMaterialPropertyByName<Real>("m_inf")),
I called it a "Real" since my function is real valued, is that correct? I didn't see anything in the documentation on how to consume ParsedFunction/ParsedMaterials.

ParsedMaterial is an "extended" form of ParsedFunction

The two systems are independent and other than the underlying function parser do not share any code. For example there is no ADParsedFunction. You cannot use the two interchangably. One is used like any other Function, one is used like any other Material.

Okay, thanks. In my case I want a user-defined function of time only to be used in the Material Interface for computing a material property. Should I be using Parsed Function, then? And if no, what's the reason for the error in the block of code I pasted above? And if yes, how do I consume ParsedFunctions? Since they're not materials, would
_m_inf(getADMaterialPropertyByName<Real>("m_inf")), still be correct?

You can use a ParsedFunction and a GenericFunctionMaterial
OR a ParsedMaterial
w/ the appropriate AD pre-fixes to the materials if you want to use AD, but AD does not matter for this material if you only have a time dependence.
The way you retrieve this material property seems fine (for AD)
or a TimeStepMaterial...

node.title: Problem about linking external library
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am now linking a external FORTRAN library ti my code. I add the "ADDITIONAL_LIBS += -L/path/to/my/lib -lname " to my Makefile. However, when I use "make" command to compile my code, there will be an error occurs:
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: warning: libgfortran.so.3, needed by /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_st_open@GFORTRAN_1.0' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_st_read@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_real_write@GFORTRAN_1.4' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_array@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_cpu_time_8@GFORTRAN_1.0' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_st_rewind@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_st_write_done@GFORTRAN_1.0' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_cpu_time_4@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_array_write@GFORTRAN_1.4' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_character_write@GFORTRAN_1.4'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_stop_numeric_f08@GFORTRAN_1.4' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_integer_write@GFORTRAN_1.4'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_character@GFORTRAN_1.0' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_stop_string@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to memcpy@GLIBC_2.14' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_real@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_st_write@GFORTRAN_1.0' /home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to _gfortran_transfer_integer@GFORTRAN_1.0'
/home/yzy/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/9.3.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/yzy/projects/full_couple/lib/libcobra.so: undefined reference to `_gfortran_st_read_done@GFORTRAN_1.0'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
/home/yzy/projects/moose/framework/app.mk:406: recipe for target '/home/yzy/projects/full_couple/full_couple-opt' failed
make: *** [/home/yzy/projects/full_couple/full_couple-opt] Error 1
I install my MOOSE through conda. Because I am not familiar with the ubuntu system, I don't know how to link this library successfully.
Any advice would be greatly appreciated!
Zhiying

Hello
It looks like your compiler is not finding libgfortran, needed to use compiled fortran code.
Let's try to locate it first, either with
whereis libgfortran or ldconfig -p | grep libgfortran
If that does not work, you'll need to download it.
@milljm does it come with the conda install?
Guillaume

Our latest environment installs libgortran 5:
(moose) [CentOS-8][~]> conda list | grep libgfortran
libgfortran-ng            9.4.0                h69a702a_8    conda-forge
libgfortran5              9.4.0                h62347ff_8    conda-forge

If your already-built-app was built using an older Fortran compiler, it will be necessary to either:

rebuild that app using the same Fortran compiler MOOSE requires (libgfortran.so.5)
or
remove the Conda MOOSE environment and install the necessary older Fortran compiler your app requires, and then build PETSc, libMesh, and MOOSE using this older Fortran compiler, so that everything matches.
Thanks for your reply very much, @milljm  and @GiudGiud. Your advice is of great help to me in solving the problem. I will try to recompile my code with libgfortran-5.

node.title: Error of being not a registered object and segmentation fault
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose expert or user,
I am studying and trying to implement a input file example called 3d.i located in the path projects/moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/rom_stress_update.
First, I try implementation in terminal and I got the following error.

Then, I try it in the peacock. The following error comes and a window pops out.

Before implementation, I already update my conda and do something about compile using 'make -j4'.
Could anyone help me with fixing this error? Thank you.
Run the executable with the --allow-test-objects option! The SS316 model is just a test for the ROM system.

--allow-test-objects

Thank you. It works in the terminal. But how can I implement it in peacock? It seems not right if I just put that at the end of the executable command line for peacock. I got 'unrecognized arguments'.

I suggest using an editor like Atom with a MOOSE syntax autocompletion plugin to edit input files, and run them from the terminal. It's a more powerful way to work with MOOSE. Unfortunately peacock is not working properly on the latest macOS for me, so I cannot reproduce your issue.

I suggest using an editor like Atom with a MOOSE syntax autocompletion plugin to edit input files, and run them from the terminal. It's a more powerful way to work with MOOSE. Unfortunately peacock is not working properly on the latest macOS for me, so I cannot reproduce your issue.

Thank you for your suggestion. I will do that.

You can add command line options in other options with peacock. See this page
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/peacock.html

node.title: EXIT CODE: 11
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
I am trying to resolve a 3D numerical problem on a cluster which does not differ from other for which I already got a converged solution in MOOSE. For some reasons I got the following error message:
Does anyone have an idea of what this could be related to?
I look forward to hearing from you.
Regards,
===================================================================================
=   BAD TERMINATION OF ONE OF YOUR APPLICATION PROCESSES
=   PID 9079 RUNNING AT node-vvvvv5
=   EXIT CODE: 11
=   CLEANING UP REMAINING PROCESSES
=   YOU CAN IGNORE THE BELOW CLEANUP MESSAGES

Hello
This could be for a variety of reasons, actual bug / running out of memory / MPI issues.
Could you please compile in debug mode (METHOD=dbg make -j XX) and re-run this a debugger?
A shorthand for it:
mpirun -n XXX gdb --ex run --ex bt --args ./your_app-dbg -i your_input_file.i
Guillaume

Hi Gulliaume,

Many thanks for your email. As I am relatively new to MOOSE, could you
please give me a bit more directions with regards to what you mean with
your command line? In fact, referring to it (see below):

mpirun -n XXX gdb --ex run --ex bt ./your_app-dbg -i your_input_file.i


   - What does XXX stand for?
   - How should I get the ./your_app-dbg? I tried to follow the
   instructions reported in the following link:

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/examples/ex21_debugging.html

Therefore I initially tried to execute the following command in the main
application folder:

METHOD=dbg make -j8

but then I got the following error message:

Makefile:19: /gpfs/cfms/home/username/projects/moose/framework/build.mk: No
such file or directory
Makefile:20: /gpfs/cfms/home/username/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk: No
such file or directory
Makefile:48: /gpfs/cfms/home/username/projects/moose/modules/modules.mk: No
such file or directory
Makefile:56: /gpfs/cfms/home/username/projects/moose/framework/app.mk: No
such file or directory
make: *** No rule to make target
`/gpfs/cfms/home/username/projects/moose/framework/app.mk'.  Stop

Hence, could you please clarify more about the details on the command line
you shared?

I look forward to hearing from you.

Yours Sincerely,

Domenico di Cugno, Ph. D.
…
On Thu, 12 Aug 2021 at 16:36, Guillaume Giudicelli ***@***.***> wrote:
 Hello

 This could be for a variety of reasons, actual bug / running out of memory
 / MPI issues.
 Could you please compile in debug mode and re-run this a debugger?
 A shorthand for it:
 mpirun -n XXX gdb --ex run --ex bt ./your_app-dbg -i your_input_file.i

 Guillaume

XX is the number of processes here.
note the --args I added to the command btw
Are you getting the same errors with the regular make command ?
Which directory are you running this from? Are you using the conda installation, if so did you remember to activate the conda environment?
Have you used gdb before? The page you linked is the right one to help you.

Hi,

Many thanks for your email and your corrections/amendments on your previous
instructions.

I assumed I should be considering the same number of processes as that I
want to make the regular run. And I also guess that XX appearing into
METHOD ... should match the XXX that you specified into the command line
mpirun ....

Are you getting the same errors with the regular make command ? Which
directory are you running this from?
Should I perform the regular make command as: make j XX I still get the
same error. However, I do not understand why is this happening as I am into
the main application directory where the *Makefile* file exists. Unless, it
is the matter of generating another MOOSE application specifically for the
debugger only?

Are you using the conda installation, if so did you remember to activate
the conda environment?
For some reason internal to the business that I work for I am not sure that
the conda activation command is needed for the cluster environment but I
might be wrong on this and I would need to double check on that. In any
cases, by running the conda activate moose the output message is: *bash:
conda: command not found*

Have you used gdb before? The page you linked is the right one to help you.
As I said, I am relatively new to MOOSE and so far I have never used gdb
before. But to be honest, by reading the webpage about debugger it is
unclear to me about which MOOSE application to consider for the debugger.

I look forward to hearing from you.

Kind Regards,

Domenico
…

 XX is the number of processes here.

 note the --args I added to the command btw

 Are you getting the same errors with the regular make command ?
 Which directory are you running this from? Are you using the conda
 installation, if so did you remember to activate the conda environment?

<https://cfms.org.uk/news-events-opinions/opinions/2021/may/make-the-most-of-automation-with-open-networking/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=gmail-footer&utm_campaign=opinions&utm_content=open-networking.>
<https://cfms.org.uk/news-events-opinions/opinions/2021/may/make-the-most-of-automation-with-open-networking/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=gmail-footer&utm_campaign=opinions&utm_content=open-networking.>

Hey
Please use the quote reply feature (next to the checkmark button) if you want to quote. Will make it easier to read.
The XX for make and the XX for mpirun do not have to match. They will match if you want to use the same number of processes for the two separate tasks, and they tend to be both equal to the number of cores that your machine has, but they do not have to.
Ok so the error does not have to do with generating the debug executable. Since you are not using conda, and are using a computing cluster where I assume someone else installed moose for you, what you need to do is specify where the MOOSE directory is before building your application. What does echo $MOOSE_DIR return?
Once this is fixed, we are trying to build a new executable specifically for debugging. Not really a new application.
gdb is not tied to moose. It's used in general for debugging. You can find a lot of help on using it just by searching online. You should be good just using the command I gave you though, once you have built the application.
Guillaume

Hi,
Many thanks for your clarifications. Here below are my thoughts:

By running the echo $MOOSE_DIR I do receive only an empty line as output. I guess this is because we compile a specific version of moose and so, at every job and within the bash file, we execute a module load command as follows:

module load /path_to_module_files/moose-vxxx
So I guess this is what echo command should give.

I can now see that it is not the case of generating a new application, but the question remain around the command I would need to generate the -gdb executable. Do I need to use the path to the moose somehow in any command line? as the METHOD= ... won't work.

Kind Regards,
Domenico

Ugh the formatting of the message is messed up again. I guess I ll just have to deal with it ^^
Ok if you are to recompile the executable in debug mode you need to have access to moose. So module load, then compile.
When compiling, either MOOSE should be in the application/moose folder, as a submodule or MOOSE_DIR should be set.

You can specify the path in the command line if you want to, so
MOOSE_DIR=path_to_moose METHOD=dbg make -j XX

It seems that something is now happening but still some errors as it cannot find few commands:

It's not finding the mpi wrapped compilers, which will compile your application with the MPI library that you are using.
You need to export the CC, CXX and FC environment variables to the location of your MPI-wrapped compilers.
If you don't know where they are, you'll need to talk to whoever installed MOOSE for you as you need to use the same compilers as those that were used to install MOOSE.

Hi,
Many thanks for your direction! Really useful! I will speak tomorrow morning UTC time zone with whoever is/was involved into the MOOSE installation.
I will keep you informed on how it goes eventually! But for now many thanks for your priceless support!
Kind Regards,
Domenico

node.title: UMAT as Plugin
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I want to learn more about using UMAT (Fortran) in moose, I tried searching it on Moose website but couldn't find much. Any help?

It was a part of the MOOSE solid mechanics module but the solid mechanics module was deprecated in favor of the tensor mechanics module and the umat code did not make it into tensor mechanics.  If you wanted to try reimplementing the umat code into tensor mechanics, you could start from this commit from 7/25/2012 which implemented umat in solid mechanics:  94051c7
I think we might try to add a umat capability back into tensor mechanics this summer.
Hi @lynnmunday is there any update on UMAT?
Stay tuned for further improvements in that area. And let us know if you have specific UMAT requirements. We're always interested in feedback on this capability!

node.title: Can not compile custom object
node.bodyText:
Hello, after I wrote DarcyPressure object in step5 of tutorial 1, I met the problem that it could not be compiled. It shows that I can't find cstdlib, whereas I myself compiled the header file containing cstdlib separately using g++. I also had this problem with the offline version of MOOSE. It seems that I didn't install MOOSE correctly. Can anyone help me please? Thanks a lot.
The following is the information returned by the terminal

   36 | #include <cstdlib>
      |          ^~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.
make: *** [/home/mestro/projects/moose/framework/build.mk:152：/home/mestro/projects/my_first/src/kernels/DarcyPressure.x86_64-conda-linux-gnu.opt.lo] 错误 1

Hello
The compiler thinks DarcyPressure is a C source file, because of the .c extension. Please rename it to .C (capital C) and let us know if that solves the issue.
Best,
Guillaume

node.title: Periodic BC for Discontinuous Galerkin
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE users,
We are implementing the DG kernels for advection, but for the moment, the periodic BC does not work.
An example input file is here https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/DGKernels/PosNegStraightEdge.i
In our view the DG kernel works only in the internal elements but for the variables on the boundaries the neighbor parts (e.g. _u_neighbor) do not work well.
Has anyone implemented Periodic BC for some Discontinuous Galerkin applications?
Any suggestion is very much appreciated.
Best Regards,
Daijun

We have noticed that periodic boundary conditions are activated only when the shape functions are FIRST LAGRANGE
but they do not work when the shape functions are CONSTANT MONOMIAL or FIRST MONOMIAL.
Does anybody know the reason for that?
And what could be a solution to make PBC working with CONSTANT MONOMIAL?
Thank you very much in advance for your suggestions.
Nicolò

Is CG having the strong continuity along the paired periodic boundaries? I am not sure if we can do that with DG. I think we should have something like a DG kernel to connect a paired sides. Do you get a run-time error for doing periodic boundary condition with DG? If not, the code at least should throw an error. Hope someone else can give you a better answer.

Hi Yaqi,
Thank you so much for your reply.
Currently we do not have an error for doing periodic boudary condition with DG kernels, it just do not work at boudary elements but the simulations can move on.
I think Nicolò's answer above points to a possible solution  for this, we want to check if there is PBC that can work with the shape function  CONSTANT MONOMIAL we are using for our simulation.
Thank you!
Best regards,
Daijun

Dear @YaqiWang
Yes, I believe CG (with first order Lagrange) with PBC removes the degrees of freedom of the variable along one of the paired surfaces, therefore there is continuity in the strong sense.
I am still not sure why this is not possible with constant monomial shape functions, it should be technically the same.
This does not depend specifically on the DGKernel, the same happens with CG,
but you never use constant monomial in that case.
Yes, as you point out, we should develop a kernel such that the variable at the neighboring element: _u_neighbor
can be fetched in the elements in the connected pair side.
Is there a function in moose that can provide the neighboring element in a periodic boundary?
The current DGKernel is not called for the boundary faces, therefore adding periodic BC has no effect,
the simulation can run though, but boundary condition remains zero flux.
Nicolò

Is there a function in moose that can provide the neighboring element in a periodic boundary?

libMesh probably has a function to allow us to find the periodic neighbor. But MOOSE probably does not have the support for properly evaluating coupled variables, material properties, etc. on the periodic neighbor. @lindsayad are these right?

Yes we have Elem::topological_neighbor for finding a periodic neighbor. @YaqiWang is right that all the plumbing in MOOSE is set up just to query and reinit finite element shape functions, variables, materials etc. for connected neighbors (neighbors accessible with elem->neighbor_ptr). It would take some changes to support periodic neighbors

node.title: Postprocessing: Total mass and total energy calculation porous flow module
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am solving a single-phase TH problem(porous_flow module)  where boundary conditions on a face are Dirichlet type for both pressure and temperature. How do I calculate the total mass and total energy for the given boundary?
Thank you,
Ranjeet

The simplest situation is when you're interested in the total flow into (or out of) the entire system.  Then you can use PorousFlowFluidMass or PorousFlowHeatEnergy.
Note that Dirichlet conditions are not recommended in PorousFlow since they frequently end up trying to withdraw fluid or heat from a region which contains none, so we try to encourage people to use one of the many PorousFlowSinks instead.
Nevertheless, Dirichlet BCs are really convenient.  So, use a PorousFlowOutflowBC to record your flux (study the save_in feature on that webpage).
@WilkAndy Thank you for the explanation. Calculated injected and produced mass using the Save-flux feature in these Boundary conditions.
